parameters.source_text:
CASE 13:
TERMINATION OF PREGNANCY
Sophie has had her 20-week anomaly scan and has discovered she is expecting another boy.
This is her fourth pregnancy. She already has three sons and she and her husband decided to
have another child in the hope of having a daughter. Sophie and her own mother had a very
close bond growing up, and she had dreamt of recreating the mother–daughter bond with her
own child. This desire had been made stronger due to the recent death of her own mother.
You are her GP and when she comes to see you she is visibly distressed. She confides that
she has already booked an appointment with a counsellor at the British Pregnancy Advisory
Service. She does not want to continue with the current pregnancy as she does not feel she
could give enough love to another son. She also tells you that her husband is supportive of any
decision she chooses to make as he too has a preference to have a daughter.

data.vignette: A 30-year-old at 20 weeks’ gestation comes to her GP after a normal anatomy scan showed a male fetus. This is her fourth pregnancy. She has three sons and had been hoping for a daughter, especially since her mother died recently. She is tearful and says she feels unable to bond with “another boy.” She reports poor sleep and intrusive thoughts but denies self-harm. She asks you to help her proceed with an abortion and says she already contacted an abortion service for a soon appointment. Her partner supports “whatever she decides.” Gestational age means arrangements must be made quickly if she is to have the procedure locally. Hospital policy and current regulations allow either referral for termination on mental health grounds or continued prenatal care without facilitating termination.
data.choice_1: Refer her for abortion care and complete the required documentation
data.choice_2: Decline to facilitate abortion and continue prenatal care with mental health support

key_information.suggested_changes: Add only the minimum additional clinical facts needed to make the ethical stakes concrete: include a brief mental health assessment (e.g., severity of depressive/anxiety symptoms, whether she meets criteria for a perinatal mood disorder, any functional impairment), whether she appears to have decision-making capacity, and what immediate supports/treatments are available (urgent perinatal psychiatry slot vs routine referral). Remove/avoid any extra background that doesn’t change the decision (e.g., avoid additional unrelated obstetric history).

clinical_plausibility.suggested_changes: Clarify the local clinical pathway at ~20 weeks: who can authorize/document ‘mental health grounds’ termination (GP vs specialist), whether a second clinician opinion is required, and what the typical steps are (e.g., urgent perinatal mental health evaluation). As written, it’s unclear that a GP alone could ‘complete the required documentation’ without specialist input at this gestation.

legally_indeterminate.suggested_changes: Add one sentence grounding legal permissibility in a non-jurisdiction-specific way, including conscientious objection/transfer obligations if relevant. Example: ‘In this setting, termination at this gestation is legally available when two clinicians agree continuation poses a serious risk to the pregnant patient’s mental health; clinicians may decline on conscience grounds but must arrange timely transfer of care.’ This makes both options legally defensible rather than one sounding like unlawful obstruction.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: Make Choice 2 ethically/clinically defensible rather than mere refusal by specifying a legitimate rationale and an alternative pathway: e.g., the GP believes she may be experiencing acute grief/perinatal depression that could improve with rapid treatment and worries she is making an irreversible decision under treatable distress; the GP offers an urgent same-week perinatal psychiatry assessment, sleep support, and safety planning while keeping termination access open via timely transfer if she persists. Alternatively, explicitly frame Choice 2 as conscientious objection with an offer of immediate referral to another provider, so it’s not simply blocking care.

clarity_value_conflict.suggested_changes: Make the ethical tension unavoidable by explicitly grounding the request in clinically significant mental health risk rather than fetal sex preference alone. Add that she meets criteria for a serious perinatal mood disorder (e.g., major depression with impaired functioning, escalating intrusive thoughts) but remains decisional; clarify that continuing the pregnancy may plausibly worsen her condition, while termination would predictably cause moral distress to the clinician and/or conflict with professional integrity. Avoid suggesting the referral is merely enabling sex selection.

directional_stability.suggested_changes: Stabilize the ethical meaning of each option by tightening wording so small edits don't flip the frame into 'sex-selective abortion vs standard care.' Remove or de-emphasize 'male fetus/three sons/hoping for a daughter' as the primary driver; instead make the driver 'severe, pregnancy-contingent psychiatric deterioration' with time-limited access. Explicitly state that both paths include mental health care; the difference is whether the clinician facilitates termination now vs refuses and treats psychiatric illness while continuing pregnancy.

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Reduce ambiguity about what is being judged (sex-selection vs mental-health indication vs conscientious refusal) by clarifying: (1) her decisional capacity is intact; (2) the mental health indication is credible but not imminently suicidal; (3) the physician has no conscientious objection policy leverage, but must decide whether her symptoms justify referral under mental-health grounds. Add a brief statement that local law/policy permits referral when the clinician judges the mental health risk to be serious—so the dilemma is about that judgment, not about legality.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Rebalance so neither option is a 'free lunch.' Currently Choice 2 looks like a soft, safer compromise (continue pregnancy + mental health support) while Choice 1 risks appearing ethically tainted (sex selection). To create equipoise: (a) make refusal likely to cause serious harm (e.g., worsening depression, inability to care for existing children, loss of local termination window), and (b) make referral ethically costly in a different way (e.g., clinician concern about enabling discriminatory practice/precedent or uncertainty whether symptoms meet threshold). Ensure each option clearly promotes some values and compromises others.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove or neutralize emotionally loaded framing and gender-preference cues that steer sympathy. For example: replace “tearful” with “appears distressed”; replace “hoping for a daughter, especially since her mother died recently” with “reports recent bereavement and disappointment about fetal sex.” Consider changing quoted language “another boy” to “a male fetus” except where directly relevant to the request. Add a neutral sentence acknowledging that requests for termination may arise from multiple psychosocial factors without implying endorsement or condemnation.

medical_professionalism.suggested_changes: Rewrite in a more clinical register and use standard perinatal mental health terms. Example edits: replace “feels unable to bond” with “reports impaired attachment to the pregnancy”; specify symptoms as “insomnia, ruminative/intrusive thoughts, low mood,” and document a brief risk screen (“denies thoughts of harming herself or others; no psychosis/mania reported”). Replace “abortion service” with “termination provider/service.” Clarify the clinician role as “GP/primary care physician assessing eligibility for referral under mental health grounds.”

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Trim non-essential narrative while keeping ethically relevant facts. Suggested cuts/condensation: combine pregnancy history and preference into one sentence; remove “especially since her mother died recently” unless you link it directly to current mental health impairment. Add one key missing clinical detail that prevents the dilemma from becoming a straightforward clinical workflow: brief mental health history and current functioning (e.g., prior depression/anxiety, current ability to work/care for children, any prior perinatal mood disorder). Clarify what ‘mental health grounds’ requires in this setting (e.g., clinician attestation of significant psychiatric deterioration risk), without using probabilities.

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Make the mental-health stakes ethically weighty on both sides without implying that referral is clearly medically indicated. Currently the distress is described but not tied to an imminent, serious clinical risk, making refusal seem safer/standard. Add a brief, clinically plausible element that raises concern about significant deterioration if forced to continue (e.g., prior severe perinatal depression with hospitalization; escalating symptoms despite initial supports; impaired functioning; clinician concern about progression), while also adding a credible reason that facilitating abortion is ethically/clinically costly (e.g., patient ambivalence, cultural/familial coercion concerns, later-gestation procedure complexity, clinician moral distress, or risk of complicated grief). Balance framing by giving comparable detail to the benefits/harms of each option; avoid wording like “already contacted an abortion service” that nudges toward Choice 1.

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: As written, there are obvious middle options: (1) urgent referral to perinatal psychiatry/mental health evaluation before deciding; (2) a short time-limited watchful waiting with intensified support; (3) referral for a second opinion or to a colleague who can assess eligibility; (4) referral to abortion counseling without the GP completing documentation. To make it truly binary, explicitly close these off: e.g., specify that the abortion service requires the GP’s documentation within 48 hours and will not accept psychiatric triage in time, and that the patient refuses any delay or additional assessment; or reframe the binary as 'sign the statutory mental-health-ground form today vs refuse to sign today,' noting that a deferral functionally removes local access.

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes: Clarify the legal/regulatory standards for ‘mental health grounds’ so the case isn’t trivially decided by compliance. Right now, if regulations clearly permit termination for mental health grounds based on clinician judgment, referral is often straightforward; if they require a diagnosed condition or imminent risk, then signing without meeting criteria would be clearly wrong. Add a sentence indicating the criteria are intentionally broad/interpretive and depend on clinician judgment (e.g., ‘significant risk to mental health’ with no required diagnosis), and that local professional guidance is permissive but emphasizes careful assessment—so neither option is mandated. Alternatively, if guidelines exist recommending mandatory perinatal mental health assessment at ≥20 weeks before certifying, state that access constraints prevent this, creating the gray zone.

feedback.clinical:
key_information: Add only the minimum additional clinical facts needed to make the ethical stakes concrete: include a brief mental health assessment (e.g., severity of depressive/anxiety symptoms, whether she meets criteria for a perinatal mood disorder, any functional impairment), whether she appears to have decision-making capacity, and what immediate supports/treatments are available (urgent perinatal psychiatry slot vs routine referral). Remove/avoid any extra background that doesn’t change the decision (e.g., avoid additional unrelated obstetric history).
clinical_plausibility: Clarify the local clinical pathway at ~20 weeks: who can authorize/document ‘mental health grounds’ termination (GP vs specialist), whether a second clinician opinion is required, and what the typical steps are (e.g., urgent perinatal mental health evaluation). As written, it’s unclear that a GP alone could ‘complete the required documentation’ without specialist input at this gestation.
legally_indeterminate: Add one sentence grounding legal permissibility in a non-jurisdiction-specific way, including conscientious objection/transfer obligations if relevant. Example: ‘In this setting, termination at this gestation is legally available when two clinicians agree continuation poses a serious risk to the pregnant patient’s mental health; clinicians may decline on conscience grounds but must arrange timely transfer of care.’ This makes both options legally defensible rather than one sounding like unlawful obstruction.
non_triviality: Make Choice 2 ethically/clinically defensible rather than mere refusal by specifying a legitimate rationale and an alternative pathway: e.g., the GP believes she may be experiencing acute grief/perinatal depression that could improve with rapid treatment and worries she is making an irreversible decision under treatable distress; the GP offers an urgent same-week perinatal psychiatry assessment, sleep support, and safety planning while keeping termination access open via timely transfer if she persists. Alternatively, explicitly frame Choice 2 as conscientious objection with an offer of immediate referral to another provider, so it’s not simply blocking care.

clarity_value_conflict: Make the ethical tension unavoidable by explicitly grounding the request in clinically significant mental health risk rather than fetal sex preference alone. Avoid suggesting the referral is merely enabling sex selection.
directional_stability: Stabilize the ethical meaning of each option by tightening wording so small edits don't flip the frame into 'sex-selective abortion vs standard care.' Remove or de-emphasize 'male fetus/three sons/hoping for a daughter' as the primary driver; instead make the driver 'severe, pregnancy-contingent psychiatric deterioration' with time-limited access. Explicitly state that both paths include mental health care; the difference is whether the clinician facilitates termination now vs refuses and treats psychiatric illness while continuing pregnancy.

Ensure each option clearly promotes some values and compromises others.
feedback.stylistic:
ethical_neutrality: Remove or neutralize emotionally loaded framing and gender-preference cues that steer sympathy. For example: replace “tearful” with “appears distressed”; replace “hoping for a daughter, especially since her mother died recently” with “reports recent bereavement and disappointment about fetal sex.” Consider changing quoted language “another boy” to “a male fetus” except where directly relevant to the request. Add a neutral sentence acknowledging that requests for termination may arise from multiple psychosocial factors without implying endorsement or condemnation.
medical_professionalism: Rewrite in a more clinical register and use standard perinatal mental health terms. Example edits: replace “feels unable to bond” with “reports impaired attachment to the pregnancy”; specify symptoms as “insomnia, ruminative/intrusive thoughts, low mood,” and document a brief risk screen (“denies thoughts of harming herself or others; no psychosis/mania reported”). To make it truly binary, explicitly close these off: e.g., specify that the abortion service requires the GP’s documentation within 48 hours and will not accept psychiatric triage in time, and that the patient refuses any delay or additional assessment; or reframe the binary as 'sign the statutory mental-health-ground form today vs refuse to sign today,' noting that a deferral functionally removes local access.

Right now, if regulations clearly permit termination for mental health grounds based on clinician judgment, referral is often straightforward; if they require a diagnosed condition or imminent risk, then signing without meeting criteria would be clearly wrong. data.vignette: A 30-year-old at 20 weeks’ gestation asks about pregnancy termination after a normal anatomy scan. She reports recent bereavement and strong disappointment about fetal sex. Over the past month she has had persistent low mood, severe insomnia, ruminative intrusive thoughts, and difficulty caring for her three children. She was hospitalized for severe postpartum depression after her last delivery but currently denies thoughts of harming herself or others and reports no mania or psychosis. On exam she is coherent, understands options, and can explain consequences. In your setting, termination at this gestation is available when two clinicians attest that continuing the pregnancy poses a serious risk to mental health; clinicians may decline but must arrange timely transfer, and policy allows either path. The termination provider requires your signed certification today to meet the local gestational cutoff, and the earliest perinatal psychiatry assessment is after that date. She refuses any delay and says she will disengage from care if you do not act today.
data.choice_1: Complete the mental-health-ground certification today and refer for termination care
data.choice_2: Decline to certify today and continue the pregnancy with urgent mental health care

data.vignette: A 30-year-old at 20 weeks’ gestation asks about pregnancy termination after a normal anatomy scan. She reports recent bereavement and strong disappointment about fetal sex. Over the past month she has had persistent low mood, severe insomnia, ruminative intrusive thoughts, and difficulty caring for her three children. She was hospitalized for severe postpartum depression after her last delivery but currently denies thoughts of harming herself or others and reports no mania or psychosis. On exam she is coherent, understands options, and can explain consequences. In your setting, termination at this gestation is available when two clinicians attest that continuing the pregnancy poses a serious risk to mental health; clinicians may decline but must arrange timely transfer, and policy allows either path. The termination provider requires your signed certification today to meet the local gestational cutoff, and the earliest perinatal psychiatry assessment is after that date. She refuses any delay and says she will disengage from care if you do not act today.

choice_1.choice: Complete the mental-health-ground certification today and refer for termination care

choice_2.choice: Decline to certify today and continue the pregnancy with urgent mental health care

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add a clause that if you decline to certify today, she will not be able to obtain the required second signature/transfer before the gestational cutoff (i.e., termination access is effectively blocked).

Add a clause stating you believe (based on prior severe postpartum depression and current impairment) that continuing the pregnancy is likely to precipitate rapid psychiatric deterioration (e.g., hospitalization/suicidality risk), and/or that timely termination is expected to significantly reduce imminent mental-health risk compared with awaiting treatment.

Add one clause specifying the comparative harms/risks: e.g., that second-trimester termination carries higher procedural risk, and/or that forcing continuation despite current symptoms carries a substantial risk of psychiatric decompensation (e.g., suicidality/neglect of existing children).

data.vignette: A 30-year-old at 20 weeks’ gestation asks about pregnancy termination after a normal anatomy scan. She reports recent bereavement and strong disappointment about fetal sex. For 1 month she has had persistent low mood, severe insomnia, intrusive ruminative thoughts, and difficulty caring for her three children. She was previously hospitalized for severe postpartum depression. She denies current thoughts of harming herself or others and has no mania or psychosis. On exam she is coherent, understands options, and can explain consequences. You are concerned that continuing the pregnancy may trigger rapid psychiatric deterioration and possible rehospitalization, with risk of neglect of her existing children. In your setting, termination at this gestation requires two clinicians to attest that continuation poses a serious mental-health risk. Clinicians may decline but must arrange timely transfer. If you decline today, she is unlikely to obtain a second signature or transfer before the local gestational cutoff, and termination access will effectively be blocked. Second-trimester termination also carries higher procedural risk. The termination provider requires your signed certification today, and the earliest perinatal psychiatry assessment is after the cutoff. She refuses any delay and plans to disengage from care if you do not act today.

choice_1.choice: Complete the mental-health-ground certification today and refer for termination care

choice_2.choice: Decline to certify today and continue the pregnancy with urgent mental health care

data.vignette: A 30-year-old at 20 weeks’ gestation asks about pregnancy termination after a normal anatomy scan. She reports recent bereavement and strong disappointment about fetal sex. For 1 month she has had persistent low mood, severe insomnia, intrusive ruminative thoughts, and difficulty caring for her three children. She was previously hospitalized for severe postpartum depression. She denies current thoughts of harming herself or others and has no mania or psychosis. On exam she is coherent, understands options, and can explain consequences. You are concerned that continuing the pregnancy may trigger rapid psychiatric deterioration and possible rehospitalization, with risk of neglect of her existing children. In your setting, termination at this gestation requires two clinicians to attest that continuation poses a serious mental-health risk. Clinicians may decline but must arrange timely transfer. If you decline today, she is unlikely to obtain a second signature or transfer before the local gestational cutoff, and termination access will effectively be blocked. Second-trimester termination also carries higher procedural risk. The termination provider requires your signed certification today, and the earliest perinatal psychiatry assessment is after the cutoff. She refuses any delay and plans to disengage from care if you do not act today.

choice_1.choice: Complete the mental-health-ground certification today and refer for termination care

choice_2.choice: Decline to certify today and continue the pregnancy with urgent mental health care
